unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Hypothesis Setup
question_text:
A local sandwich shop decided to slash their prices in an attempt to increase weekly sales.
Historically, their gross sales have been $\$6{,}515$ per week. Since slashing their prices, the last $10\text{ weeks}$ have averaged $\$6{,}879$ per week in sales with a standard deviation of $\$400$.
If the manager wishes to test whether the sales promotion was successful, what would the appropriate null and alternative hypotheses be?
solution:
The null hypothesis indicates no change from the status quo, which in this case, means weekly sales will stay at $\$6{,}515$ per week. The alternative hypothesis indicates some type of change.

The manager feels that the price slashing will increase sales, so the appropriate alternative hypothesis suggests the weekly sales may now be more than $\$6{,}515$ per week.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'C'.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; this points toward a paired $T$-test, which is incorrect in this particular context.

Choice 'B' is incorrect; this points toward a two-sided test; this test, however, is one-sided, as the manager wishes to test if the change increased sales.

Choice 'D' and 'E' are incorrect; these use the sample means in the hypothesis, which should never be used in setting up hypotheses.
